text: thank you priyanka and hi everyone and
welcome to kubecon
i'm cheryl i'm the vp of ecosystem at
the cncf
and today i want to talk about why end
users are not just
passive consumers but first of all
let me say how much i miss being
together with all of you
kubecon is a different experience every
single time
we have had freezing snow in austin
we've had floods in san diego and every
time the
community finds a way to really pull
together
i particularly want to welcome you if
this is your very first kubecon
so from past events we know that 70 of
attendees are first-timers
so if that includes you then
welcome and i'm really glad that you can
be here
and let me tell you a little secret
about conferences
the talks the content you're going to
hear in the next few days are great
but what i really enjoy is
talking to people finding out about what
they're doing
and learning about them and of course
that's going to be much harder in a
virtual conference
than when it is when i can just grab
a coffee with you so
i want you to do something for me right
now
i want you to open up a text editor
and i want you to write one line
and this one line will say i'm your name
and i want to chat about
whatever whatever so maybe you are new
to cloud and containers and you just
want to know like what is this
kubernetes thing
does it even make sense for me maybe
you've been using it for a little while
and you're thinking am i making the
right technical choices
what do other people use or maybe you
really love cloud native
so you're thinking how can i contribute
more how do i get my
team and my organization to really care
about
open source so
keep this line and put it into the text
chat
and introduce yourself right now and
then
keep introducing yourself over the next
three days
every time that you go to a talk or go
to a booth
use that same line and just keep
introducing yourself
because the more times that you
introduce yourself
the more chances you'll have to meet
someone who wants to talk about the same
things that you do
so why don't i reintroduce myself
i'm cheryl and i want to talk about why
end users are not just
passive consumers so
of course we all start as end users
i remember in fact the first time that i
discovered linux
i was 17 i was just about to go to
university
as a computer science student and
i needed a new computer so i went online
i asked
what do computer science students
usually use
and someone said well you can use
whatever you want
but you see you should probably check
out linux
so it's like linux okay i've never heard
of this but i guess
i do what the internet tells me to do so
i downloaded ubuntu and i burnt it to a
cd
and i very carefully wrote on the
outside l
u n i x
like i knew so little about linux that i
didn't even know how to spell it i wrote
lunix on the front of this and
that was my first taste of open source
of linux
and to go from there now to being part
of the linux foundation
and driving open source it's just been
really fun for me
so when i talk about why end users are
more than passive consumers
by end users i mean people who adopt
cloud native infrastructure
but they're not selling any cloud native
products
or services so this includes the
150 companies in the cntf end user
community
which is the bit that i run and
what i see with this community is that
just to use cloud native you already
have to have a
certain level of sophistication
but to run it at scale like these
companies are doing
is so much harder because you have so
many choices it's not just choices like
do i need a service mesh or not
is choices like how do i build the best
possible developer experience or
how do i track what i'm spending and
keep control of the costs
and people tell me all the time like hey
i've looked at the cncf landscape
i'm just overwhelmed there's too many
choices where do i even
begin so it got me to thinking that
if you could ask these 150 companies
what they
use you would probably have a pretty
good idea
of what they think is valuable and what
they recommend
so that's what i did i created
something called the cncf end user
technology
radar with the idea to share some of
this real world experience
from end users and every quarter we
would pick a different use case
and we would ask people what do you
really recommend
so here is the first one and
the first one is on continuous delivery
so if i were picking continuous delivery
solution
i would look at the things that are in
the center as
more companies have used those and
recommend them
and then i would go from adopt i would
go to the next ring to trial and look at
those ones
and then i would take a look at the rest
of the projects after that
and why do i think this is important
so to me this is important because you
have to have a real
world view of cloud native it's more
than just
open source it's more than just any one
product
or project and the only way that you can
figure out what will work for you
is by learning from others by getting
that real world experience
from other end users which is why end
users are not just passive consumers
they have so much experience to share
so if you're feeling overwhelmed i
recommend you check out the cncf end
user technology radar
keep an eye on it we're publishing the
next one very soon in september
and if you want your voice to be heard
on the technology radar
then please come and join the cncf and
user community
and meet your peers
lastly i want to say that if you're
attending kubecon
don't be a passive consumer don't just
sit back and watch
but whether or not you're contributing
to open source
you have so much to share so much
experience
and this is what kubecon is really about
it's about
connecting with people it's about being
part of the community
it's about sharing what you know and
helping others
and even if all that you can share is
something as simple as
use linux then maybe you're helping a 17
year old
who is on her way to becoming a software
engineer
so keep introducing yourself have a
fantastic kubecon
thank you very much
